ovdesc.p: This table contains all details of each individual Currency, for example, Currency Name, Number of Decimal places together with other information such as the Buy and Sell Rates.

T24 caters for both Middle rate and Buy/Sell Rate environments therefore when installing the System the User must specify, in the Company record, which method is to be adopted. Regardless of which rates are entered, however, both Middle and Buy/Sell Rates are used in calculations e.g.
- Middle Rate is used for monitoring of rate variances; - Buy/Sell Rates are used (in conjunction with spreads) to calculate Treasury/Customer rates.

Automatically, when the Middle Rate and the Default Spread are entered, the Buy/Sell Rates are calculated and when Buy/Sell Rates are input the Middle Rate and the Default spread will be calculated by the System.

The use of the I.S.O. Currency Codes are recommended as a standard for the ID of this table although an additional numeric code must be defined and may be used as an alternative ID for accessing the Currency details.
Up to 999 additional elements may be defined according to local requirements.
To assist the user, we are including below explanations of the two methods used to quote exchange rates.

1) The first method is used in countries where the local currency is being quoted and the foreign currency is the variable amount. This is the practice followed in U.K. where the GBP/USD quotation, for example, will be expressed as 1.2500 and not as 0.8000. This case will be referred to as UK type environment.

2) The second method is used in countries where the foreign currency is being quoted and the local currency is the variable amount. This is the practice followed by Europe, for example, in France, the USD/FRF quotation will be expressed as 8.7500 and not as 0.1143. This case will be referred to as Non-UK type environment.

It must be noted that the words BUY and SELL used in the various examples always denotes the action of the bank (e.g. CUSTOMER BUY RATE will mean the rate at which the bank is buying the Currency from the Customer).
UK TYPE ENVIRONMENT ===================
Middle Rate System ------------------
INPUT : MIDDLE RATE and DEFAULT SPREAD CALCULATED : BUY RATE = (Middle + Default Spread) SELL RATE = (Middle - Default Spread)
Buy/Sell Rate System --------------------
INPUT : BUY RATE and SELL RATE CALCULATED : MIDDLE RATE = (Buy + Sell/2) : DEFAULT SPREAD = (Middle - Sell)
Note : In this environment, the BUY RATE will be GREATER than the SELL RATE.
Example : If you are in London, the Deutsche Mark and French Francs quotations will be:
NON-UK TYPE ENVIRONMENT =======================
Middle Rate System ------------------
INPUT : MIDDLE RATE and DEFAULT SPREAD CALCULATED : BUY RATE = (Middle - Default Spread) : SELL RATE = (Middle + Default Spread)
Buy/Sell Rate System --------------------
INPUT : BUY RATE and SELL RATE CALCULATED : MIDDLE RATE = (Buy + Sell)/2 : DEFAULT SPREAD = (Sell - Middle)
Note : In this environment, the BUY RATE will be LESS than the SELL RATE.
Example :
In Germany, the American dollar and the Pound Sterling quotations will look like:

Each Currency record caters for different Currency Markets thereby providing up to 9 different rate structures. This facility can be utilised when physical markets exist, e.g. Financial and Convertible Markets or where pricing considerations require differing rates or spreads (e.g. Transfers/Notes/Travellers cheques). For the examples in this Overview only one Currency Market has been used.
For each Currency the user can specify a Negotiable Amount, i.e. an amount, above which, the Treasury rate must be obtained from the dealer.

Treasury and Customer Spreads will be defaulted from the CURRENCY record unless a specific rate and spread is input on the Transaction. Where only a rate is input (this will be taken as the Treasury Rate) the default Customer Spread will be added/subtracted to obtain the Customer Rate.
Where only a Customer Spread is input on the Transaction the System will default the Treasury Rate.

Note : Each Module, e.g. FOREIGN EXCHANGE, FUNDS TRANSFER or DATA.CAPTURE will define whether rates input are treated as Treasury or Customer Rates and whether input of a rate is compulsory for Transactions in excess of the Negotiable Amount.
The Treasury Buy/Sell rates are the rates at which Treasury units buy/sell foreign currency from/to the Marketing units.

The Exchange rates quoted to Customers are determined by Marketing units by defining the appropriate Customer Spread to be added/subtracted to/from the Treasury Buy/Sell Rates. (Refer to following examples)
i) UK Type Environment - Currency Rate Concept -------------------
MARKET BUY RATE MARKET SELL RATE (+) plus/minus (-) TREASURY SPREAD equals
TREASURY BUY RATE TREASURY SELL RATE (+) plus/minus (-) CUSTOMER SPREAD equals
CUSTOMER BUY RATE CUSTOMER SELL RATE
Example : DEFAULT RATE CALCULATION (UK-GBP/USD) - MARKET MIDDLE RATE = 1.2500 MARKET DEFAULT SPREAD = 0.0015
MARKET BUY RATE = 1.2515 MARKET SELL RATE = 1.2485 TREASURY SPREAD = 0.0050
TREASURY BUY RATE = 1.2565 TREASURY SELL RATE = 1.2435 CUSTOMER SPREAD = 0.0100
CUSTOMER BUY RATE = 1.2665 CUSTOMER SELL RATE = 1.2335
Note : In the UK type environment, the BUY RATES are GREATER than the SELL RATES.
ii) Non-UK Type Environment - Currency Rate Concept -----------------------
MARKET BUY RATE MARKET SELL RATE (-) minus/plus (+) TREASURY SPREAD equals
TREASURY BUY RATE TREASURY SELL RATE (-) minus/plus (+) CUSTOMER SPREAD equals
CUSTOMER BUY RATE CUSTOMER SELL RATE
Example : DEFAULT RATE CALCULATION (Germany-USD/DEM) MARKET MIDDLE RATE = 3.09 MARKET DEFAULT SPREAD = 0.0030
MARKET BUY RATE = 3.0870 MARKET SELL RATE = 3.0930 TREASURY SPREAD = 0.0100
TREASURY BUY RATE = 3.0770 TREASURY SELL RATE = 3.1030 CUSTOMER SPREAD = 0.0125
CUSTOMER BUY RATE = 3.0645 CUSTOMER SELL RATE = 3.1155
Note : In the Non-UK type environment, the BUY RATES are LESS than the SELL RATES.
Allocation of Exchange Profit -----------------------------

As mentioned earlier, the final exchange rates quoted to Customers (Customer Buy Rate and Sell Rate) are determined by Marketing units by defining the appropriate Customer spread (Customer Small Spread and Medium Spread) to be added/subtracted to/from the Treasury Buy/Sell Rates.

The allocation of exchange earnings is then made automatically between Treasury and Marketing units at the time of the deal/transaction in that any profit relating to the Marketing area (Customer Spread) is credited to Profit or Loss immediately and the deal is effectively booked at Treasury Buy/Sell Rates. All exchange profit or loss on revaluation therefore accrues to the Treasury area.

To assist the user, various examples follow to illustrate the allocation of the Foreign Exchange Profit between the Marketing and the Treasury areas. The first example illustrates a transaction where the local currency is involved. The second and third examples depict transactions where both currencies are foreign.

Note : The examples reflect the method of quoting rates in the UK, i.e. where the local currency is the currency being quoted. For countries where the foreign currency is the currency being quoted, the Buy and Sell Rates are interchanged.
ALLOCATION (FGN/LOCAL) ======================
EXAMPLE 1 - Buy FCY from a customer against local CCY -----------------------------------------------------
i.e. CUSTOMER SELLS $1000.00 AGAINST LCY
DR CASH $1000.00 at 1.2565 (Treasury Rate) = LCY 795.86 CR CUST $1000.00 at 1.2665 (Customer Rate) = LCY 789.58 CR P+L (Being CUSTOMER SPREAD OF 0.01) LCY 6.28
The Customer will thus receive 789.58 against the USD 1,000.00 and the marketing profit on the transaction is GBP 6.28.
EXAMPLE 2 - Sell FCY to a customer against local CCY ----------------------------------------------------
i.e. CUSTOMER BUYS $1000.00 AGAINST LCY
CR CASH $1000.00 at 1.2435 (Treasury Rate) = LCY 804.18 DR CUST $1000.00 at 1.2335 (Customer Rate) = LCY 810.70 CR P+L (Being CUSTOMER SPREAD of 0.01) LCY 6.52
The Customer will have to pay GBP 810.70 to buy USD 1,000.00 and the marketing profit on the transaction is GBP 6.52.
MARKETING EXCHANGE PROFIT ALLOCATION (FGN/FGN) ============================================== (Buy FCY from a customer against another FCY)

On transactions involving two foreign currencies, the System will automatically take the spread on the currency which is NOT the "BASE" currency (the default base currency being the currency which yields a cross rate greater than "1").

For the "BASE" currency, the System will then take the Middle Rate. The user has, however, the facility to specify the base currency if he does not want to the System to work on the default value. Examples of these options follow. In Example 3 the "default base currency" is "DEM". This is because its value is greater than "FRF".
EXAMPLE 2 - Base Currency = DEM (Default) ----------------------------------------- (Customer sells FRF 6000.00 against DEM)
DR CASH FRF 6000.00 at 11.50 (Treasury Rate) = LCY 521.74 CR CUST DEM 2006.40 at 3.8625 (Middle Rate) = LCY 519.48 CR PROFIT AND LOSS = LCY 2.26
CROSS RATE = 2.9903
The Customer will thus receive DEM 2,006.40 against the FRF 6,000.00 and the marketing profit on the transaction is GBP 2.26.
The accounting entries shown represent the result of this Transaction and the actual sequence of events is detailed hereafter.
STEP 1 : CALCULATE CUSTOMER BUY RATE FOR FRF AGAINST LCY MARKET MIDDLE RATE = 11.4000 MARKET DEFAULT SPREAD = 0.05
MARKET BUY RATE = 11.4500 MARKET SELL RATE = 11.3500 TREASURY SPREAD = 0.05
TREASURY BUY RATE = 11.5000 TREASURY SELL RATE = 11.3000 CUSTOMER SPREAD = 0.05
CUSTOMER BUY RATE = 11.5500 CUSTOMER SELL RATE = 11.2500
Therefore customer FRF Buy Rate = 11.5500
STEP 2 : OBTAIN DEM MIDDLE RATE AGAINST LCY
DEM Middle Rate = 3.8625 (i.e. 3.09 * 1.25)
STEP 3 : CALCULATE CROSS RATES
CUSTOMER CROSS RATE = (11.55/3.8625) = 2.9903 TREASURY CROSS RATE = (11.50/3.8625) = 2.977346
Note : This time, the exchange cross rates are expressed as French Franc per Deutsche Mark because the DEM has been specified as the base currency.
STEP 4 : CALCULATE DEM EQUIVALENTS
FRF 6000.00 at 2.9903 (Customer Rate) = DEM 2006.40 FRF 6000.00 at 2.9773 (Treasury Rate) = DEM 2015.22
STEP 5 : EFFECTIVE RESULT
DR CASH FRF 6000.00 at 11.50 = LCY 521.74 CR CUST DEM 2006.49 at 3.8625 = LCY 519.48 CR P+L (DEM 8.73 at 3.8625) = LCY 2.26 (i.e. the difference)
EXAMPLE 4 - Base Currency = FRF (specified by the user) -------------------------------------------------------
(Customer sells DEM 6,000.00 against FRF)
DR CASH DEM 6000.00 at 3.8965 (Treasury Rate) = LCY 1539.84 CR CUST FRF 17478.00 at 11.40 (Middle Rate) = LCY 1533.16 CR PROFIT AND LOSS = LCY 6.68
CROSS RATE = 3.343289
The Customer will thus receive FRF 17,478.00 against the DEM 6,000.00 and the marketing profit on the transaction is LCY 6.68.
The accounting entries shown represent the result of this transaction and the actual sequence of events is detailed hereafter.
STEP 1 : CALCULATE CUSTOMER BUY RATE FOR DEM AGAINST LCY
MARKET MIDDLE RATE = 3.8625 MARKET DEFAULT SPREAD = 0.0170
MARKET BUY RATE = 3.8795 MARKET SELL RATE = 3.8455 TREASURY SPREAD = 0.0170
TREASURY BUY RATE = 3.8965 TREASURY SELL RATE = 3.8285 CUSTOMER SPREAD = 0.0170
CUSTOMER BUY RATE = 3.9135 CUSTOMER SELL RATE = 3.8115
Therefore Customer DEM BUY RATE = 3.9135
STEP 2 : OBTAIN FRF MIDDLE RATE AGAINST LCY
FRF Middle Rate = 11.4000
STEP 3 : CALCULATE CROSS RATE
CUSTOMER CROSS RATE = (3.9135/11.40) = 0.343289 TREASURY CROSS RATE = (3.8965/11.40) = 0.3417985
Note : The exchange Cross Rates are expressed as Deutsche Mark per French Franc because FRF has been selected as the base currency.
STEP 4 : CALCULATE FRF EQUIVALENTS
DEM 6000.00 at 0.3432 (Customer Rate) = FRF 17478.00 DEM 6000.00 at 0.3417 (Treasury Rate) = FRF 17554.20
STEP 5 : EFFECTIVE RESULT
DR CASH DEM 6000.00 at 3.8965 = LCY 1539.84 CR CUST FRF 17478.00 at 11.40 = LCY 1533.16 CR P+L (FRF 76.20 at 11.40) = LCY 6.68

desc.p: A time entered in this field will be used to determine the cut off point for default value dates on FUNDS.TRANSFER transactions.
For outgoing FUNDS.TRANSFER transactions this field will be used in conjunction with
CUT.OFF.RULE on the AGENCY file, if these fields have both been set, the default DEBIT.VALUE.DATE will be determines as follows:

If the transaction is entered before the cut off time on the currency file (for the debit currency) and CUT.OFF.RULE contains 0, then the debit value date will be today’s date, if CUT.OFF.RULE contains 1, then the debit value date will be today’s date +1 working day. If the transaction is entered after the cut off time on the currency file (for the debit currency) and CUT.OFF.RULE contains 0, then the debit value date will be the next working day, if CUT.OFF.RULE contains 1, then the debit value date will be the next working day +1 working day. Specifies the numeric code which corresponds to the alpha ID. This code must be unique and provides an alternative means of referencing the Currency details in T24 Applications.

The code may be set by banks currently using Numeric Currency Codes thus allowing these same codes to continue in use (in effect acting as a translation table). It could, alternatively, be set to standard codes used in a particular Country for central bank reporting, etc. Another use is to set these codes according to the frequency of use of the various Currencies. If, most transactions are, for example, in US dollars, Deutsche Marks and Belgian francs you could the Numeric Currency Codes could be allocated as follows:
1 : to US Dollar 2 : to Deutsche Mark 3 : to Belgian Franc
These short codes can then be used in Transaction Processing Applications to minimise the input required.

Defines the amount above which the exchange rate to be used must be obtained from the dealer.
The purpose of this field is to define a maximum amount for which the Rates specified in this record can be used without reference to the dealers.

The exchange rate on transactions, below the specified value, need not be input. Based on the applicable Rates, Spreads and Condition tables, the System will apply the appropriate rate, and calculate the local currency equivalent.

Transactions which exceed the amount specified should be booked with the dealers, and the rate obtained should be input. Any rate input will be treated as the Treasury rate, and for this reason only the Customer Medium Spread will be added/subtracted to/from it to determine the Customer Buy/Sell rate.

For transactions which exceed the negotiable amount, the System will still allow to default the rates applicable to smaller transactions but in this case an override will be required to force the transaction with the existing Rates.

Note : Input in this field will be allowed for local currency and will be used in the case, for example, where the Customer asks to pay in a Foreign currency the equivalent of 10.000 units of the local currency.

desc.p: The type of rounding to be applied to cash transactions in this currency.
The value in this field specifies the type of rounding, or rounding rule, to be applied by the system for cash transaction amounts.
The possible values are ( ‘1’, ‘2’,’3’,’NONE’)
If set to ‘1’ or ‘NONE’, then the natural rounding is applied
If set to ‘2’, then rounding down is applied
If set to ‘3’, then rounding up is applied
If no value is given, then defaulted to '1' for natural rounding.
Defines the percentage variance allowed on the Middle Rate for any rates entered, to control that exchange rates and spreads entered in the T24 system are within the allowable range.
The Default Rate Allowance for all Currencies is specified in the Company record. Where this default is inappropriate you may enter a Specific Rate Allowance for this Currency.
An override will be required to accept any Rate outside the variance specified in this field.

Identifies the method of quotation of the exchange rate.
Market practice makes use of two basic methods for organising the quotation of Currencies:

1. UK Type Environment The first method of exchange rate quotation refers to those countries where the local currency is the Currency being quoted and the foreign currency is the variable amount. In U.K., for example, the exchange rates will always be expressed against the Pound Sterling (their local currency).

2. Non-UK Type Environment The second method of exchange rate quotation refers to those countries where the foreign currency is the Currency being quoted and the local Currency is the variable amount. In Germany, for example, the exchange rates will always be expressed against the foreign currency (e.g. 1 USD = 2,98 DEM; 1 GBP = 3,8625 DEM etc...). As a further requirement, in this environment, it must be possible to indicate the number of units of the foreign currency which is used to express the exchange rate.

In Belgium, the US dollar or the Pound Sterling exchange rates will be expressed in single unit (i.e. 1 USD = 60 BEF or 1 GBP = 80 BEF) while for smaller value currencies like the Italian Lira and the Japanese Yen, the exchange rates will be expressed in 100 units (i.e. 100 ITL = 3 BEF or 100 JPY = 24 BEF).
Therefore, for this environment, this FIELD allows you to define this number of units as details in the following table:
Value Meaning
0 1 UNIT of the foreign currency 1 10 UNITS " " 2 100 UNITS " " 3 1000 UNITS " " 4 10000 UNITS " " 5 100000 UNITS " "
Example: If you are in Belgium you will define for:
Currency Quotation Code
USD 0 GBP 0 DEM 0 ITL 2 JPY 2 etc.

Great care must be taken by the user when defining the value of this field, because all the exchange rates quoted against the local currency will take this value into account in currency conversion and verification. When a cross-rate is quoted between two foreign currencies, a direct rate will be expressed irrespective of the quotation code on either currency. A similar cross-rate will, therefore, apply in both the UK and non-UK type environment.
Note : For those countries which quote their own currency (UK Type environment), it has been supposed that the foreign currency is always expressed against 1 UNIT of the local currency.

Defines whether this currency is fixed to another currency for example an "in" currency linked to the Euro.
In this case for all currency conversions in the system the fixed rate defined in FIXED.CCY will be used to convert rates and amounts to the fixing currency before converting to the other currency.
Conversion from an "in" currency to the fixing currency will be from the "in" currency to the fixing currency via the fixed rate.

Conversion between two "in" currencies will be from currency 1 to the fixing currency using the fixed rate for currency 1 then from the fixing currency to currency 2 using the fixed rate for currency 2.

Conversion between an "in" currency to an "out" currency will be from the fixed rate for the "in" currency to the fixing currency, then from the floating rate of the fixing currency to the "out" currency.
N.B. for the Euro group of "in" currencies
All "in" currency fixed rates are quoted as units of currency to 1 Euro.
Conversion to the Euro will be by dividing the "in" amount by the fixed rate to give the Euro amount
Conversion from the Euro will be by multiplying the Euro amount by the fixed rate to give the "in" amount.

For example the first group of currencies with rates fixed to the Euro will begin on 1 January 1999.

Indicates the amount to be added to/ subtracted from MID.REVAL.RATE to obtain the Market Buy/Sell Rates.

The field reflects the actual market spread between Middle and Buy/Sell Rates. It is important to realise that the addition/subtraction of this spread to/from the middle rate will generate the Market Buy/Sell rates and not the final Customer Buy/Sell rates. The latter will be identified by the addition/subtraction of the appropriate Treasury and Customer spreads to the Market Buy/Sell rates.

Up to 10 type R characters plus a decimal point. Standard rate format 6,9. (when input allowed). Associated Multivalue Field. Input not allowed for local currency. Mandatory input for Middle Rate System, otherwise no input allowed.
In a Middle Rate installation this is a mandatory field (except for the local currency) and the rate input is added to/subtracted from MID.REVAL.RATE to obtain the Market Buy/Sell Rate.
In a Buy/Sell installation input is not allowed to this field. The system calculates this spread by comparing MID.REVAL.RATE to SELL.RATE.
When allowed to be input, the default market spread must be smaller than the Middle Rate.

Indicates the Market Sell Rate. Used as a base for calculating (default) rates for Customer Transactions (those less than the negotiable amount). In a Buy/Sell installation this Rate must be input whereas in a Middle Rate environment this Rate is calculated automatically and therefore cannot be input.

When installing T24 the user must decide which Currency environment is to be adopted locally. The Company record contains a field which specifies whether a BUY/SELL RATE or a MIDDLE RATE system is to be used:
1. Buy/Sell System

This field is mandatory (except for local currency) and in conjunction with BUY.RATE the System automatically calculates the Middle Rate. The resultant difference between Sell and Middle Rates is then taken as the value of DEFAULT.SPREAD.
2. Middle Rate System
No input is allowed to this field. Rates are input using the Middle and Default Spread Rate fields and the Market Sell Rate is calculated automatically.
When amending this rate it is checked to be within the specified tolerance of the existing rate. An override is required if out of tolerance.

Note : The Sell Rate is the Market Sell Rate and not the final Customer Sell Rate. The latter will be identified by the addition/subtraction of the appropriate Treasury and Customer Spreads to this market Sell Rate.

Specifies the decimal displacement of a PIP when the Currency is quoted against US dollars or Pounds sterling.

The Foreign Exchange Application allows for exchange rates to be input as (+/-) a number of pips when one of the Currencies of the transaction is USD or GBP. These pips (premium/discount) will then be added to/subtracted from a datum rate (e.g. the number of PIPS defined on the forward leg of a SWAP contract will be added to/subtracted from the SPOT rate entered in the spot leg). This field defines the decimal displacement, and therefore the value, of 1 PIP when dealing against US dollars or Pounds Sterling.
Example:

The dealer makes a SWAP contract USD/DEM by which he is buying SPOT US dollars at 2.9675 against Deutsche Marks and selling 3 months FORWARD US Dollars against Deutsche Marks at a discount of 300 PIPS.
If the DEM Currency has been defined with the value of 4 in the field Quotation PIPS, the System will then convert the discount of 300 PIPS with a 4 decimal displacement as follows:
INPUT RESULT SPOT LEG 2.9675 2.9675 FWD LEG - 300 - 0.0300 FWD RATE 2.9375
In consequence adding or subtracting 300 PIPS is equivalent to adding or subtracting 0.0300 when the quotation PIPS of the currency is 4.

Note : (i) It has been assumed that the quotation PIPS of any Currency is the same against US Dollars and Pound Sterling. This is a true statement today but should this practice change, an appropriate maintenance will then be required in this field.
(ii) The use of PIPS is only available in the Foreign Exchange Application.
1 numeric character in the range 1-6. (Optional input. No default value).

Identifies to which market the following rates apply in those countries where more than one market exists to determine the exchange rates of foreign currencies.

All Transaction Processing Applications contain a data element Currency Market and any input made in this field will be checked against this table to derive or verify the appropriate exchange rate of the transaction. The exchange rates applicable to the Market 1 will always be defaulted if no other input has been done.

For the local currency input in this FIELD will also be allowed to permit the user to use, if required, the fields Quotation Suspense and Negotiable Amount. These are the only 2 fields of the association which will be allowed for the local currency.

A typical example is Belgium where foreign currencies are quoted on the Convertible/Regular market and also on the Financial/Free market. Different sets of exchange rates will exist according to these two markets and this explains the reason and the purpose of this field.

The CURRENCY table allows you to identify, if required, up to nine different markets and consequently to define for each foreign currency up to nine different sets of exchange rates. The System will always force you to define at least one set of rates, i.e. to define the exchange rates applicable to the currency Market 1 which will be the default currency Market used by all Transaction processing applications.

It must also be noted that this CURRENCY.MARKET field can also be used within the concept of notional market, i.e. where you would like to define different sets of exchange rates according to the type of product handled. One set of exchange rates, for example, could be defined to identify the exchange rates applicable to your Notes transactions, set of rates for travellers cheques, another set of rates for your transfer transactions, etc.
2 numeric characters. Market 1 must always be input. Associated multivalue field.

For all the countries where more than one market exists for the determination of the exchange rates, input of the various markets in this field will be essential to ensure a correct definition of the exchange rates applicable to the various markets.
The Currency Market 1 will always be mandatory.
If a market >= 10, the market indicated in the first digit must be already present on the record.

Indicates the date of the Fixing Rates and will only be used by those countries where exchange rates for the major currencies are "fixed" daily between the banks and the local central bank. This field will therefore identify the date on which the exchange rates were last loaded.

For those countries where "Fixing Rates" practice is applicable, the value of this field will be checked by the FUNDS.TRANSFER Application to determine if the Fixing Rates have already been input for the Run day. When the fixing date is not equal to the Run date, Funds Transfer transactions where amounts need to be converted at today's fixing rate will still be processed and can be authorised but will be flagged with a specific Funds Transfer status (ANORATE). When the Fixing Rates have been finally entered, a batch program FT RATES will then recognise these transactions and finalise the processing of the transactions.

For the countries where the Fixing rate practice is applicable, the user should enter a fixing date only for those currencies which are part of the fixing. In Belgium, for example, around 20 currencies are Fixed every day between the Central Bank and the commercial banks. Only these 20 currencies will then require input in this field when the fixing rates are entered in the table.

Up to 9 type D date characters. (Date format in range 1950-2049.) Optional input, not allowed for local currency. Default = Null (i.e. blank) which will denote that this Currency is not in a Fixing Rate environment.
The date input in this field can never be greater than the Run date.
Any date prior to the Run date will request an override and a maximum of 7 days back value will be allowed.

During the processing of Funds Transfer Transactions if the today's fixing rates are not yet available, the application will still default the last available rate but will request an override if that rate has to be used.

If a Treasury and Customer medium spread have been input while the Treasury and Customer small spreads were not entered, the system will then use the medium spread for all amounts up to the negotiable amount. For any amount above the negotiable amount only the Customer medium spread will be applicable.

If the Treasury and Customer medium spreads are not input while both the UPTO.SMALL.AMT and the NEGOTIABLE.AMT have been entered, the system will take no spread on any transaction which exceeds the UPTO.SMALL.AMT. Example: The following example (based on UK environment exchange rate quotation) is an illustration of the concept and the relation of these various spread fields with UPTO.SMALL.AMT and NEGOTIABLE.AMT. Let us suppose that Wonder bank London branch applies the following rules for the transactions involving conversion in US Dollars. 1) UPTO.SMALL.AMT = USD 1,000.00. 2) NEGOTIABLE.AMT = USD 10,000.00, i.e. for any transaction involving a conversion in USD for an amount greater than USD 10,000.00, the exchange rate must be requested from the dealer. 3) TRSY.SMALL.SPRD = 0.0060 4) CUST.SMALL.SPRD = 0.0100 5) TRSY.MED.SPREAD = 0.0030 6) CUST.MED.SPREAD = 0.0050 7) BUY.RATE = 1.2520 8) SELL.RATE = 1.2500 Then the following default values will apply if the bank is selling US Dollars against Pound Sterling to the Customer. Specifies the date after which the currency is available for use.

When a new currency is introduced the currency code will be required in the system to allow related tables to defined, however it may not be valid to raise accounting movements and payments before the account is officially available. Indicates whether a currency should always be the base currency for currency conversions, in the event that a base currency has not been supplied to the conversion routine.
The actual value is defined in the CURRENCY.PARAM record for this currency.
Each currency can optionally be assigned a unique base currency rank in the same manner as currency rank. The values are stored in the application RANK.BASE.CURRENCY.
If two currencies are involved in a conversion and both have a base ccy rank defined then the currency with the lowest rank will take preference.
N.B. It has been stated that rates to the EURO (EUR) will always be quoted as the number of other currency units to 1 EUR, even when 1 unit of the other currency is worth more than 1 EUR.

Example : assuming that 0.71 GBP were worth 1 EUR then the effect of not supplying a base currency or rate to the conversion routine would result in the base currency being set to GBP and the rate expressed as the inverse of 0.71 i.e 1.408451.
Setting the EUR to have a base currency rank of 1 would result in the EUR being the base currency and the rate to be 0.71.

Great care should be taken when defining a currency to have a base currency rank. There are in fact very few instances where this should be used. One example as discussed is the EURO. Another example would relate to the Irish punt in a situation where the local currency has been converted to be the Euro.

Market practice in Ireland is to quote all foreign currencies to 1 unit of local including GBP, so for example GBP in Ireland will be quoted as say 0.8 GBP to 1 IEP, with EUR as local currency the system will default the rate to be the inverse of this i.e 1.25 IEP to 1 GBP. To retain the current market practice with EUR as the local currency then EUR should be defined with the lowest rank and IEP with the second lowest rank.
This siuation may also apply when converting from a GBP local currency to EUR.
